intro.description: This cheat sheet helps you to open an ascii file, and shows you how to show the derivative of this data If you have just completed the previous cheat sheet, please close all your data file parts.

item.title: Data Browsing Perspective
item.description: Please choose the data browsing perspective if you do not already have it selected (nothing will happen if you do not).

item.title: Open File
item.description:
Click to open an example file from the 'data' project containing multi-channel analyser data.
This file is found in 'data->examples->96356.dat'

item.title: Plot One Data Set
item.description: In the 'Data' column of the part, select the item labelled 'FileNum' and then the 'sum' item. This will plot the values of 'sum' vs. 'FileNum'.

item.title: Select 'Derivative' tool
item.description: Now on the toolbar above this plot, there will be a drop down of available tools. These tools may be obscured on Linux if the window containing the plot is too small. On the drop down action labelled 'Plotting tools (used for images and X/Y plots)' select the 'Derivative' tool. You will see the tool become available under the plot, and the plot become the derivative of what was being observed.

item.title: View the other derivatives or the raw data
item.description:
In the Derivative tool, there are several checkboxes which toggle the display of the various derivatives, check them all on to see all the data and derivatives overlaid.
You can also un-select them in the same way, just keep the derivative selected( f'(Data) )

item.title: Derivatives of other traces
item.description:
If you select another trace to plot whilst the derivative tool is open, this will also be displayed appropriately
Select the item labelled 'sum' in the data window, you will see the derivative appear. The checkboxes now effect all the plots.

item.title: Clearing the derivatives
item.description: To clear all the derivatives from the plot, select the Clear Tool from the tool menu. This will then get you back to the raw data.

item.title: Processing the derivatives
item.description:
If you wish to form some further operation on the derivatives, simply select the tool you wish to use, without going to the Clear Tool between the other tools.
For example, select 'sum' only from the data table, and then select the Derivative tool.
Now select the Measurement Tool and you will notice that the Derivative tool disappears, but the plot stays of the derivative.
You can now use the measurement tool to measure the distance between the positive and negative peak.
